author: Minimum-Watercress-8
body:
SEC v. Craig = a fucking idiot who literally tried to pose as investment firms (see facts of the case) by creating fake Twitter accounts WITH THOSE FIRMS' NAMES. This isn't just securities fraud, it's fraud on a whole different spectrum. If you were to tweet "PLTR is going bankrupt in 30 days" from meta-cognizant, just like the fucker in Craig did, you would be fine.

SEC v. McKeown = fucking idiots who were literally compensated by the companies that they were pumping (manipulation based on incentives from the actual fucking fraudulent company should scream no-no to you) and dumping.

Not even close to what we have here. Like could not be further, I cannot emphasize enough lol

author: heldforsale
body:
Valid post. Also reading between the lines, most Bloomberg rumor articles include something along the lines of "a deal could be announced as soon as this week". The CCIV/Lucid article did not have that language. Indicates to me that the talks may be in an earlier stage. 

To be clear, I am long CCIV. Just have to be cognizant of the ratio of upside to downside and weigh perceived probabilities.

author: wft227
body: Funds buying up what they can after hours causing price to drop. Probably trying to start a panic sale. Be cognizant and enjoy your tendies

author: Im_shorting_elon
body:
I wouldn't say the market itself is in a bubble but certain sectors are. Big ones right off the bat are the Energy/EV sector (TSLA, ENPH, PLUG, NIO, etc.), the Genomics sector (EDIT, CRSPR, FATE, PACB), some tech/cloud (APPS, SE, FVRR), and some miscellaneous stocks (PENN!!!, RICK, CELH) etc. Genomics and EV specifically because they are supposedly the future. No doubt they are but that's what everyone was saying about the internet back in 1999, 2000, and it really took about 10 years for those stocks that crashed but survived to *really* get going (MSFT, ADBE, AMZN, PCLN, etc.), some haven't even recovered still, such as Cisco and MicroStrategy.

Do keep in mind that the DOW has risen 12k+ points in just 10 months and some bubbles have already popped or on the decline (think NKLA or ZM).

When you say "everyone", do you mean people on this subreddit or people in your daily life? I've noticed on these forums people are a bit more cognizant of what's going on, so they know that a lot of these valuations don't make sense but in the outside world, I know and have heard of plenty of people buying stocks on Robinhood because "BuY tHe DiP!!" is constantly blasted on social media and through word of mouth. For example, I know someone who bought US Foods on Robinhood for no particular reason. 

These stocks go down once:

A. Fed decides to increase interest rates

B. Black Swan Event, which is possible given the state of affairs at this point in time.

author: WengersOut

author: heyumigotaquestion
body:
I haven't time for some of the other bits right now I'm sure others will cover, but know that paper trading doesn't take into account genuine volume often. So if you learn via paper trading, then make sure what you trade when you trade for realsies is high volume. Otherwise your perfect trade won't take place in reality since nobody wants it at that volume in that spread.

Essentially, in reality nobody is buying one billion shares of that, so be cognizant that paper trading doesn't truly reflect reality in that regard.

author: DickBatman
body:
> (Today's data will be available tomorrow.)

It's fucking tomorrow right now /u/meta-cognizant.

author: hoodedcactus
body:
If I think it’ll stay above, then I’ll hold until ~a week before. 

If I think it’ll keep mooning, sometimes I’ll roll the short leg up. I hardly do this as most of my spreads started so deep otm it would be miraculous to keep going

Or, if I don’t see it staying above, I’ll sell for partial profit early. 

If you hold towards expiry, be cognizant of short interest / dividends and if your short leg is at risk of early assignment.

author: H_Logan
body: This guy talking about *cognizant* lol.

author: kriegkopf
body: We have the truth and the facts on our side, I hope it will prevail in the end. We just need to be cognizant of the fact that there is a lot of bad-faith actors operating on these forums right now and to ignore disinformation and deception. I'm just glad more and more people are becoming aware of the underhanded tactics MM's and the media is playing. This is spreading like wildfire so people will just become aware that media outlets like CNBC and Bloomberg exists to serve these hedge fund managers.

author: One_Situation_2725
body: Probably but you need to be cognizant of the risk and not end up overleveraged in case things go tits up.

author: jn_ku
body:
No problem--I try.  I'll probably write a follow-up post to respond to as many broad questions as possible since I just can't get back to everyone.

That begin said, your question was a good one that I'm sure is on many peoples' minds, so I'm hoping it's seen by others who have the same question.

I know that some people are, for various reasons, happy to see the whole thing burn down, but I am very cognizant that there are real world consequences for many people to all of this, and that watching this unfold can be very scary if you have no framework from which to understand events.

author: Rotatos
body: Yep its ServiceNow, thanks for the reminder. I still cannot believe the market isn't cognizant of BB actually being what it is

author: In4matics
body: Cognizant > Palantir

author: Sardisthemagian
body: Just wanted to emphasize the point you're making. I thought it was a good idea to sell puts on GME around 30 pre squeeze, but of course i would have made far more just buying more of the stock. This whole episode is making me more cognizant of the risk of capping upside just to get a discount on a stock you like. You leave yourself completely unexposed to positive black swans.

author: Burninglightstorm
body: I would like a world like that too, and I know how hard it is to lose a significant chunk of of money, but things are going to change soon because they have to.  Shorting is the next thing to go, but there are always going to be a certain number of ruthless blood suckers in any sector. You have to be careful and do the research. Seasoned investors know that biopharma is very, very risky, so if they decide to invest in them, they are taking a long shot which could pay in a big way, but if they lose they won't lose too much because they were fully cognizant of that too. That's what I did knowing full well that it could go bust, but I like to scatter 1 or 2 longshots in my portfolio. My other longshot was Cannabix. It seems to be picking up now. Really, I'm sorry to hear about anyone losing, but in the end it's all a learning experience isn't it.

author: memesupreme0
body:
Because Billionaire Propaganda has convinced a large swathe of voters that "regulation bad" so those worker protections, ie regulations, have been steadily eroded over the decades to what we have now.

Not all regulation is good, but not all de-regulation is good either, we have to find a sweet spot and be cognizant that we're only 350m ish people on a rock with 8b+ other people, some antagonistic, some sympathetic.

That requires an education that is being constantly fought against by those billionares that need voters to think they're doing the right thing by siding with the aristocrats instead of their neighbors.

author: agamenc
body:
No, but I’d check to make sure none of the ETFs you’re in have TSLA (or at least be cognizant of how much TSLA you have).

Also be aware that it’s value is very much inflated beyond earnings, so massive growth is already priced in and bad news could tank it. If you’re prepared to take those risks I think it’s fine.

author: uwuglock19
body:
I'm a filmmaker, I'm long AMC because I know that theaters are going to open back up again. Simply enough. Look at my post history. Just because you can't comprehend a companies valuation beyond an article you've read on the news doesn't mean that others can't or don't see or feel something different. And who are you to decide what a companies valuation is? Are you an economist? Or is it just your opinion that AMC isn't worth $15? 

 I don't care about the ethics of the market, the market doesn't care about ethics to begin with. So telling investors they should be cognizant of shit outside of their own TA and DD is pretty elitist. There are short hedges BETTING to put people out of jobs, leaving THEM to hold the bag. 

What you're seeing is new money supporting brands that they like, because they like them. And maybe you should take some time to understand that instead of looking down upon them as if *your* perspectives as a trader are somehow more righteous. In the end, the ones holding the bag will be the ones who entered into shit positions. 

That's how it is with EVERY trade. That's how options work. When you buy a call, that's someone else' put. So by your logic, you shouldn't even be trading to be honest.

author: LifeHasLeft
body: Yeah I was cognizant of this meme stock as a WSB lurker for a while but I have basically $0 of expendable income, and I have kids to feed...sucks but I can’t afford to YOLO on a meme stock right now

author: TrumansOneHandMan
body:
what do you mean? I'm insanely lucky. on the one hand, I have to live with my parents, but on the other, I *get* to live with my parents. I don't pay rent and I don't have to worry about my next meal. as miserable as I am, I'm still cognizant of that.

my worst nightmare is someone who is having trouble making rent reading my comment and deciding then and there to take a risk he can't afford and then this goes tits up, he gets a surprise bill, and then he's on the street, or he gets fired because his car won't get him to work anymore. me and him take the same loss, I'm just one paycheck behind where I could have been. it's not the same. like I said--this goes tits up, my life sucks cock just as much as it did yesterday. that isn't true for everyone.

author: key_kid_1
body:
trading marijuana is illegal. it isn't illegal like shutting down a stock trading platform at crucial crowd sourcing moments, though. it is illegal like convincing a bunch of voters to move to a place and influence the laws. not like shutting down a trading platform. go long. buy for the long term.

I am a self-cognizant robot

author: formallyhuman
body:
I agree. I haven't been subbed long but I came into this being fully cognizant that I could very easily lose anything I put into any stock. So, I've only put in money I have, and which I am comfortable losing. And certainly nothing on margin.

I've seen more than one person say they've made huge gains on a small investment but are holding for no other reason than they think, based on the hype, that it'll go higher. I just wish people would pull enough out to cover their initial investment and, sure, then let the rest ride if you want.

author: uwuglock19
body:
It does but that’s why you hedge & think a bit more asymmetric. A crash, short squeeze, “WSB hype”; any market activity can be capitalized if you’re cognizant of indicators. 

A lot of us new money just have different risk tolerance than old money. It’s 2021 & people are going to miss the bus if they don’t step up.

author: KennanFan
body:
Why would they sell at a loss instead of just warehousing it?  Referring to this as  a "strategic initiative" immediately after stating they sold this inventory at a $2.9 million to $3.2 million loss seems like a strategy to take off the sting.

They also said the average price is now reduced by 50%.  All that means is that the cost of producing what they sold at a loss was way too high.  It's great they they've achieved greater efficiency with regards to their newer inventory; let's just be cognizant about what came before.

I'm long Valens.  This is a great company that is operating in a flawed environment (e.g. poor cannabis 2.0 rollout overall, vaping scare.)

body: He just got appointed to be Vice Chairman of IBM - some people think he wont be focused on his SPAC for a while. But you could make the case that he just opened a whole new world of potential contacts within tech.

author: SPAC-ey-McSpacface
body:
I'd say "most" SPACs.  Warrant prices are just silly.  Over the last 3 trading sessions I've been liquidating almost all of my warrants & putting the money back into commons of the underlying.

One odd exception is CRHC Units, which are actually cheaper than Commons + Warrants.  I have a lot of CRHC Units, but I'm tempted to add even more for three reasons.

1. I like the team / SPAC
2. I like the fact Cohn just signed on with IBM today.  I didnt see anyone mention this as a CRHC readthrough & the SPAC wasnt up much today, but I cant imagine Cohn takes that job unless they already have a target.
3. Them seem, IMO, cheap all things being equal

author: jackcrj
body:
What’s interesting is I think ibm is making some very smart moves now: cloud..sure, blockchain..yes so many practical uses, ai..this will eventually be a tsunami, quantum computer..holy$h*t this will bring tremendous change to computing and security of computing.

Tldr ibm and today surely is not a 100 bagger but they are poised to continue delivering

author: Jclevs11
body:
I find it incredibly disconcerting (I have CNBC on all day at work in my office) when I watch Morgan Stanley say TSLA's new PT is $810, the very next day it goes above that and beyond. That is fucking scary. I had a great opportunity to buy TSLA when i bought a ton when the pandemic hit, but i couldnt do it. I cant trust the company, and it sounds like many people are in that same boat. 

It's been pump and dump for a couple years now. Its gonna dump soon. You cannot say with a straight face that TSLA is more valuable than American Express, Boeing, Goldman Sachs, Caterpillar, Ford, GM, IBM and Dow Chemicals COMBINED. That is just fucking ridiculous. And now its market cap is greater than the top automotive makers in the world COMBINED. that doesnt make any fucking sense no matter what moon or planet youre on.

author: SPAC-ey-McSpacface
body:
I'm just going to lay down a speculative prediction marker here that I think CRHC is going to announce a target soon.

Commons hit an all-time high yesterday & units are hitting an all-time high today on unusually high volume, and this comes after Cohn just got hired by IBM, and I find it difficult to believe he'd take a new job unless his > $800M SPAC had a target.  Putting 2+2 together, I'm thinking they're close.

author: Catheter_Trader
body: When is IBM gonna start rolling out news on the quantum computers and entangled processor chips?

author: AXdssd5as
body:
But if Bitcoin is being bought by investors as a store of value, i.e. how it is marketed as "digital gold", isn't this a bit dangerous since unlike gold, it can have identical competitors, and just because it is on-top now doesn't mean it always will be?

Gold has been a store of value because of its relatively finite quantity at any given time, but also because of several other qualities that are hard to replicate in other materials (it doesn't rust or corrode or tarnish, it is soft enough to be shaped easily, it is rare but not too rare etc).

Unlike gold, Bitcoin is replicable, either identically or near-identically, which means that it could become more like a stock in the future, and if that's the case, the fact that it is on-top now doesn't necessarily mean this will continue? Companies that have seemed unassailable (AT&T, IBM, Kodak) have fallen, meanwhile gold has been around for however many thousands of years and still hasn't been dethroned (except maybe eventually by Bitcoin!)

author: Somethingdifferent39
body:
I average up all the time. I started buying SQ at $98 and stopped around $160. I would still buy more at $218 but its already taken over a large portion of my portfolio so I wont for diversity reasons.

To your question, you will likely find that you will be mpre successful averaging up than down, as counter intuitive as it may seem. You could have averaged up on AMZN, AAPL, and MSFT at any point in the past decade and be very happy with the result.

Likewise you could have averaged down on XOM, IBM, and GE over the last 10 years and been very dissapointed. More often than not the long term trend is justified. Your job as an investor is to figure out where the company is headed next.

Hello, 

Just wanted to get some advice here I have some ideas, but thought I’d reach out. So my mother is transferring her 401k from her previous employer and I will manage it for her. I wanted to get some thoughts on asset allocation. 

Her scenario is she doesn’t need this money within the next 10 years at least. She is still working self employed. She is 60 doesn’t have any debt has other passive income (rentals), cure t holding are random funds her employer had with mass mutual they will be liquidated into cash and put into a traditional Roth. Risk tolerance I would say a 5 out of 10 (10 being very risky).

My thoughts where to select a handful of dividend stocks for 50-60% i like names such as jnj, mmm, xom, T, pg, Abbv, csco, ibm (trying to stick with dividend champion companies that are reasonably priced now..) etc and then the remaining 20% would be in a couple vanguard bond funds and remaining 20% in a vanguard s&p fund. 

Any inout would be great this isn’t her complete retirement fund it is a small portion and 1 of 3 of her retirement accounts. 

Thanks,

Seems that Mendix, Appian, Bettyblocks and Microsoft are more focused on commercial markets and offer simpler and cheaper solutions (I believe Bettyblocks is actually no-code). Which is smart because there are a lot of potential customers in that market that don't use low code platforms yet. So I do see future in it, but the question is which companies are going to become the market leaders.

author: tomorland
body:
Ok, let's talk about Tesla.

For the record, I do not own any Tesla stock, nor do I own a Tesla car, nor do I plan to own either in the foreseeable future. (I \*do\* own an electric car that I built myself. Love it. Planning to convert my daughter's car soon.)

Here's why I think Tesla's stock value *could* be justified and *may* continue to go up.

1. Tesla is a car company that makes a profit. It's not Amazon. But then, Amazon *didn't* make a profit for a long, long time. Amazon's retail product delivery service still doesn't make a profit. Who could have known that Amazon would beat Microsoft, Oracle, Cisco, Walmart, Akamai and all the others at cloud services? AWS is the meat of Amazon's profits. Who could have predicted this when they were just a book store?
2. Tesla is also a consumer goods company. Solar power is just the tip of the iceberg. Heat pumps, Smart Homes, Satellite Networking... Yes, it's a tech company -- but it's more than that, it's a *BRAND*. Brand is far more valuable than innovation. The story you sell is more effective than the product you sell, *especially* if it's an also-ran product...
3. Musk only knows one way to manage -- like a startup. Still going strong, like a start-up, after all these years.
4. Leverage. Space-X, Boring Co. Tesla and whatever else comes along -- Grid-scale electrical storage? Off-grid self-sufficient housing? Insurance services? They all share tech between them. Tesla's Octo-valve, for instance. Almost certainly was designed by an aerospace engineer at Space-X.
5. Tesla isn't Apple, or Amazon, or Microsoft. It's more like Java (the programming language) in the late 1990s.  Java didn't do anything better than any other language could do. It was a far worse language than many other more suitable, more mature ones. It failed at its main promise (write once, run anywhere!) Most seasoned programmers laughed at it. They said it wouldn't last. And yet...

So, forget about the cars. Tesla is a *brand*. It's a consumer technology-goods company that got it's start with cars, like Amazon got its start with books until it found gold in cloud services. Tesla is still digging, currently using a constellation of satellites... It won't end there. That's guaranteed.

Having said that, keep in mind that any one of IBM, Oracle, Walmart or a dozen others *could* have eaten Amazon's lunch at any time. Amazon was lucky no one tried very hard.

author: walnuts24
body:
Good points.  As a reference, prior to 2020 (2010-2019) my annualized return has been about 18%.  Usually my individual stocks way outperform my index funds or mutual funds but I don’t have time to research for hours and hours.  My investments have always been owned longer than a year, most closer to 5+ years or almost the entire duration.  My main holdings over the 2010-2019 (pre-COVID) period were Microsoft ($28 cost basis), Disney ($46 cost basis), Nike ($55) and Xylem ($50).  I got ‘lucky’ and dumped Disney when Iger stepped down in February out of nowhere at $135.  I never bought back in and I should have. I did have some duds such as IBM and GE over that time that dragged me down, but I can’t complain.  This year I did well but I traded more than usual and lost my cost basis for everything out of panic selling.  The trades I made were Zillow ($78-115), Starbucks ($78-103), Penn ($3-15), NIO ($3-16) and some losses like Slack and CARA.  Now I have only my 401K and a bit of sector ETF (I love ARKK).  

Hindsight, I screwed up and should have just held all my positions but I just kept jumping around to catch waves.  I didn’t realize they were never going to stop! Haha. Now I’m looking at everything thinking “they have to correct” and I’m not sure they will.  Which is why I have yet to get back in.

author: AXdssd5as
body:
But if Bitcoin is being bought by investors as a store of value, i.e. how it is marketed as "digital gold", isn't this a bit dangerous since unlike gold, it can have identical competitors, and just because it is on-top now doesn't mean it always will be?

Gold has been a store of value because of its relatively finite quantity at any given time, but also because of several other qualities that are hard to replicate in other materials (it doesn't rust or corrode or tarnish, it is soft enough to be shaped easily, it is rare but not too rare etc).

Unlike gold, Bitcoin is replicable, either identically or near-identically, which means that it could become more like a stock in the future, and if that's the case, the fact that it is on-top now doesn't necessarily mean this will continue? Companies that have seemed unassailable (AT&T, IBM, Kodak) have fallen, meanwhile gold has been around for however many thousands of years and still hasn't been dethroned (except maybe eventually by Bitcoin!)

author: Raleigh_Noles
body:
I have to disagree. While a lot of us are doing good work researching and investing in fields and technology we use and buy, and getting in earlier into the future Boeing’s, Mastercards, IBM, Ford etc.
You have millions or hundreds of thousands of pump and dumpers on WSB or YouTube pump and dumping vag cream companies. That’s the domino or canary that makes this scary. And will ultimately doom a lot of this market.
The kid who has a $5k Robinhood account, gains a huge following pushing penny stocks, only to crash and burn. You get enough of those kind of stories and retail will coward away. Creating a new generation who is fearful of investing.... Chris Saca is a prime example of how history will repeat itself.

Bloomberg, Marketwatch, Fortune parading around newly minted millionaires always terrifies me, because that usually signals things getting out of hand...... Beenie babies, Pokémon cards, tulips, Bitcoin.

author: Somethingdifferent39
body:
I average up all the time. I started buying SQ at $98 and stopped around $160. I would still buy more at $218 but its already taken over a large portion of my portfolio so I wont for diversity reasons.

To your question, you will likely find that you will be mpre successful averaging up than down, as counter intuitive as it may seem. You could have averaged up on AMZN, AAPL, and MSFT at any point in the past decade and be very happy with the result.

Likewise you could have averaged down on XOM, IBM, and GE over the last 10 years and been very dissapointed. More often than not the long term trend is justified. Your job as an investor is to figure out where the company is headed next.

author: The-Crazed-Crusader
body:
Thanks for article. And from other things I found it seems that IBM failed to compete because they were too competitive. Not only the buybacks, but there were expensive ventures by buying up large cloud companies that made no money of consequence. They actually started losing when they missed the PC train. And recently, yes they've been spending fortunes on competitive business practices while only spending enough on science to keep their products relevant... While the other guy was following the Edison model of the business of science (money obtained from the last patent funds the next invention).

Who is to blame? IDK, I ain't an insider.

author: redderper
body:
I'm working with low code software myself as a developer. It's a small world. I learned recently when I bought an ETF that has Appian how much it gained and I'm quite surprised because I haven't heard of anyone or any company that uses it.

Most popular players in the low code fields are IBM, Salesforce, Pegasystems and more recently I see Mendix, Microsoft and Bettyblocks gaining some traction. Don't know a lot about Appian yet, but I'm going to look into it

author: 9tacos
body: Maybe PLTR could do that in the future. Right now, they have a proprietary analytics platform that they customize specifically for the workload.  It doesn’t look like a pure cloud SaaS business,  more like a hybrid / consulting services model like IBM.  The good thing is that they are being valued like a cloud SaaS.  Hopefully, this demo day reveals some more information.  I like the contracts they are landing and am I’m holding for 2021.

author: redderper
body:
IBM has a seemingly never ending revenue stream from governments and financial companies. Part of it is from mainframes and legacy systems, but they also did a lot of acquisitions of smaller tech companies in the last 10 years that have the more innovative stuff.

They have lost a lot of market share from other tech companies like Microsoft and Amazon webservices, so they're not growing much anymore. Still think it's a good bluechip stock to hold

author: redderper
body:
At the moment it is because low code isn't that popular yet outside of government, banking and insurance (which IBM and Pega is mostly focused on). Salesforce is very popular though, but mostly as a CRM platform. The others focus more on what is called BPM or process automation.

Seems that Mendix, Appian, Bettyblocks and Microsoft are more focused on commercial markets and offer simpler and cheaper solutions (I believe Bettyblocks is actually no-code). Which is smart because there are a lot of potential customers in that market that don't use low code platforms yet. So I do see future in it, but the question is which companies are going to become the market leaders.

author: tomorland
body:
Ok, let's talk about Tesla.

For the record, I do not own any Tesla stock, nor do I own a Tesla car, nor do I plan to own either in the foreseeable future. (I \*do\* own an electric car that I built myself. Love it. Planning to convert my daughter's car soon.)

Here's why I think Tesla's stock value *could* be justified and *may* continue to go up.

1. Tesla is a car company that makes a profit. It's not Amazon. But then, Amazon *didn't* make a profit for a long, long time. Amazon's retail product delivery service still doesn't make a profit. Who could have known that Amazon would beat Microsoft, Oracle, Cisco, Walmart, Akamai and all the others at cloud services? AWS is the meat of Amazon's profits. Who could have predicted this when they were just a book store?
2. Tesla is also a consumer goods company. Solar power is just the tip of the iceberg. Heat pumps, Smart Homes, Satellite Networking... Yes, it's a tech company -- but it's more than that, it's a *BRAND*. Brand is far more valuable than innovation. The story you sell is more effective than the product you sell, *especially* if it's an also-ran product...
3. Musk only knows one way to manage -- like a startup. Still going strong, like a start-up, after all these years.
4. Leverage. Space-X, Boring Co. Tesla and whatever else comes along -- Grid-scale electrical storage? Off-grid self-sufficient housing? Insurance services? They all share tech between them. Tesla's Octo-valve, for instance. Almost certainly was designed by an aerospace engineer at Space-X.
5. Tesla isn't Apple, or Amazon, or Microsoft. It's more like Java (the programming language) in the late 1990s.  Java didn't do anything better than any other language could do. It was a far worse language than many other more suitable, more mature ones. It failed at its main promise (write once, run anywhere!) Most seasoned programmers laughed at it. They said it wouldn't last. And yet...

So, forget about the cars. Tesla is a *brand*. It's a consumer technology-goods company that got it's start with cars, like Amazon got its start with books until it found gold in cloud services. Tesla is still digging, currently using a constellation of satellites... It won't end there. That's guaranteed.

Having said that, keep in mind that any one of IBM, Oracle, Walmart or a dozen others *could* have eaten Amazon's lunch at any time. Amazon was lucky no one tried very hard.
